Guilt, guilt, bat eyelashes, bat eyelashes, etc.

You know what, Konami, I don&#39;t even care 
about Silent Hill anymore. You make all

the Pachinko machines and arcade shooters and 
Pyramid Head-shaped suppository kits you like.

I loved Silent Hill once, but you know what, 
getting us attached to name franchises is how

they get you. That&#39;s why Disney can sell haunted 
Zyklon-B canisters just by sticking C3PO on the

front. I don&#39;t want a new Silent Hill, I want 
interesting new horror games that benefit

from Silent Hill&#39;s influence. I like bands 
influenced by Nirvana but I wouldn&#39;t like it

if they nailed Kurt Cobain&#39;s body to the front 
of the drum kit. Well, you&#39;re in luck, Yahtzee,

me drivelling old game reviewing giant sea turtle, 
because here&#39;s The Medium, a new original survival

horror game not only inspired by Silent Hill but 
featuring music from Akira Yamaoka, himself. Yeah,

all the shitty Silent Hills had music from Akira 
Yamaoka. So did the Dead by Daylight expansion,

and Shadows of the Damned, and... World 
of Tanks?! Akira Yamaoka apparently has

trouble saying no to people. And why are you 
trying to cover the developer logo? Erm. &#39;Cos

it&#39;s by Bloober Team. Ugh. Fucking walking 
simulator merchants. Wish they&#39;d simulate

walking over to a fucking whiteboard and 
coming up with some new ideas for once.

Oh but this isn&#39;t another first person walking 
simulator - it uses a fixed third person camera

in direct reference to classic survival horrors! 
Hm, consider me on board for now, Bloober Team,

but the moment you make me backtrack through 
a door that inexplicably leads to somewhere

different I&#39;m making you play my new get 
kicked up the arse simulator. For you see,

that camera thing tells me something significant: 
that someone gets it. Someone gets that the third

person fixed camera adds to the atmospheric sense 
of detachment that survival horror benefits from.

Feels more like you&#39;re being watched from the 
shadows by parties unknown and less like you&#39;re

nestled up against the protagonist&#39;s nice warm 
buttocks the whole time. Some people might say

The Medium hardly needs it though since the 
atmosphere of detachment is adequately created

by the personalities of all the characters but 
those would be some terribly cruel people. Anyway,

The Medium is about a twentysomething girl who 
wears clothes of a size somewhere between small

and large and also has the ability to perceive the 
spirit world and talk to the recently dead.

She gets called out to an abandoned vacation 
facility and site of a famous massacre to

uncover the sinister truth behind both it and her 
mysterious origins and get some material for her

urban exploration Youtube channel. This might 
sound weird, but it took me a while to figure

out that this fixed camera survival horror game 
with a gloomy atmosphere about exploring both a

decrepit real world and an identically laid 
out scary netherworld that looks like it&#39;s

made primarily out of ham, was supposed to be 
Silent Hill inspired. Talk about missing the

Otherworld for the crucified bodies on spikes. I 
guess I just wasn&#39;t picking up the same vibe. It

reminded me more of Dark Seed, that old point 
and click adventure game about exploring an

H.R. Giger-designed parallel dark world as the 
protagonist struggles to overcome the horror of

their moustache. Silent Hill feels organic and 
visceral and wet, The Medium felt more dead and

dusty and as dry as a newlywed baptist who doesn&#39;t 
believe in foreplay. Some kind of combat element

might have helped. I don&#39;t say that because 
Silent Hill had combat, Silent Hill combat

was like the stick in the ice lolly, serving 
a purpose but not the part you want to chew

on - it really seemed like The Medium was gonna 
have a combat element, but then it didn&#39;t.

All the pieces were in place. We establish that 
ghosts can hurt us, and that we&#39;re going to a

place with more ghosts than the bargain bin at the 
Call of Duty shop, and that the main character can

load up her arm with spirit juice to fuel a blast 
attack and a shield, so I was like, great, ghost

laser tag, let&#39;s Luigi&#39;s Mansion this bitch. But 
then we don&#39;t get that. Your blast attack is used

mainly for clearing clutter out of the way like 
it&#39;s a fucking astral leafblower and the closest

thing to combat is the odd forced stealth stroke 
evasion sequence against a recurring monster who

kills you in one hit, which is about as engaging 
as such things ever are, that is, as much as

holding in a fart at a distant cousin&#39;s wedding. 
And then at the end of each act the main character

- who I seem to remember having a name but it&#39;s 
one of many things about The Medium I struggle

to hold in my memory - confronts a big elaborate 
monster spirit form of whoever&#39;s been stirring up

the trouble most recently and it really seems like 
a setup for a boss fight, and then whatshername

just defeats them in the same cutscene with no 
bother. Look, I&#39;m not asking for an exchange

of ectoplasm bullets as our flaky protagonist 
dodge rolls about like Sonic the Hedgehog.

But the artists seem to have put a lot of work 
into the monster designs and I&#39;m sure it&#39;d feel

more worth it if we had a chance to explore all 
their jiggly flaps looking for the weak spots.

On the monsters, I mean, not the artists. Combat 
isn&#39;t just a distraction to keep the twitchy kids

occupied while mum and dad are stroking their 
chins at the random document pickups - to a

horror game it adds context and engagement. 
Having to use a machete to hack aside the

undergrowth in your path is what separates jungle 
exploration from a nature hike. The running theme

of my time with The Medium is that I always felt 
like I was more skating along the top of it than

getting immersed. The gameplay didn&#39;t grab 
me. It&#39;s the usual survival horror inventory

puzzle stuff - explore environment, find door 
blocked by rabid polecat, explore a bit more,

find can of rabid polecat repellent etc - but the 
level design constantly herds us towards progress

and I never felt like I was the one coming up 
with the solutions. Case in point, there&#39;s a bit

where the recurring monster is stomping about 
and we have to evade it until we find a way to

restart a generator, at which point main character 
lady said &quot;Aha, now I can turn the tables on the

monster!&quot; and I was like &quot;You can? It&#39;s really not 
clear how. You gonna plug in a Karaoke machine and

challenge it to a Something Stupid-off?&quot;
I also wasn&#39;t grabbed by the story. Although

that might be retroactively because of the 
ending. If your plane ends up crashing in

the mountains it&#39;s hard to have fond memories of 
the airline&#39;s hot towel service. Token warning:

Just call me an auto shop for douchebags &#39;cos 
there&#39;s a ton of spoilers coming in. Basically,

the main character - Marianne? I think it was 
Marianne - finds the person who caused everything,

and said person asks her to shoot them to stop 
the monster. And Marianne decides she&#39;s gotten

really attached to this person in the nine seconds 
they&#39;ve had to talk and proposes instead to shoot

herself, which would also stop the monster by some 
awkward logic I wasn&#39;t quite convinced by. The

argument escalates for a bit, then cut to black, 
gunshot, roll credits. So she either shot herself

or didn&#39;t, guess it&#39;ll depend on sequel viability. 
The Medium has good visual design and atmosphere,

but I wasn&#39;t thinking about those during my 
suddenly much freer afternoon. I was wondering

why violent ballistic death leapt that quickly 
to the top of Marianne&#39;s proposed solutions list.

Just felt really out of nowhere. Failure 
of characterisation, I suppose. The suicide

ending made sense in Spec Ops The Line, and 
Silent Hill 2, and my last school reunion.
